records.content: A mean-reversion strategy based on statistical price extremes.

Middle band = moving average

Upper/Lower bands = standard deviation envelopes
Price crosses above lower band
Price crosses below upper band

Self-adjusting

Strong statistical foundation

Poor in strong trends

Vulnerable during crashes

//@version=6
strategy("Bollinger Bands Strategy", overlay=true)

length = input.int(20)
mult = input.float(2)

basis = ta.sma(close, length)
dev = mult * ta.stdev(close, length)

upper = basis + dev
lower = basis - dev

if ta.crossover(close, lower)
    strategy.entry("Long", strategy.long)

if ta.crossunder(close, upper)
    strategy.entry("Short", strategy.short)

A pure momentum-based strategy inspired by the famous Turtle Traders.

Upper Bound = highest price in N periods

Lower Bound = lowest price in N periods

Trade only when price breaks these levels
Price breaks above upper bound
Price breaks below lower bound

Captures large trends

Simple logic

Works across all markets

False breakouts

Poor performance in sideways markets

//@version=6
strategy("ChannelBreakOutStrategy", overlay=true)

length = input.int(5)
upBound = ta.highest(high, length)
downBound = ta.lowest(low, length)

strategy.entry("Long", strategy.long, stop=upBound)
strategy.entry("Short", strategy.short, stop=downBound)

# Greedy Strategy (Pyramiding Gap Strategy)

The Greedy Strategy aggressively adds positions when the market moves in your favor.

## Why â€œGreedyâ€?

- Uses **pyramiding**
- Allows up to **100 simultaneous trades**
- Designed to maximize gains in strong moves

## Trade Logic

### Entry
- Gap-up above previous high â†’ buy
- Strong close â†’ add more positions

### Protection
- Intraday trade limit
- Small fixed profit target

## Pros
- Huge profits in strong trends
- Uses stop orders
- Built-in trade limits

## Cons
- High margin requirement
- Very risky during reversals

## Improvements
- ATR-based targets
- Trend filters
- Scaled position sizing

//@version=6
strategy("Greedy Strategy", pyramiding=100, overlay=true)

tp = input(10, "Take profit")
sl = input(10, "Stop loss")
maxidf = input(5, "Max intraday trades")

strategy.risk.max_intraday_filled_orders(maxidf)

upGap = open > high[1]
dnGap = open < low[1]

if upGap
    strategy.entry("GapUp", strategy.long, stop=high[1])

if dnGap
    strategy.entry("GapDn", strategy.short, stop=low[1])

This book contains algorithmic trading strategies with explanations and code.
The MACD Strategy is one of the most famous tools used by traders to catch shifts in market momentum.

MACD stands for Moving Average Convergence Divergence.It compares two different â€œspeedsâ€ of the market to understand strength.

Fast Line (12-period) â€“ reacts quickly to price

Slow Line (26-period) â€“ moves smoothly

Signal Line (9-period) â€“ confirms momentum changes
The strategy looks at the difference (Delta) between fast and slow averages.

Fast line crosses above slow line

Delta crosses above zero

Fast line crosses below slow line

Delta crosses below zero

Excellent for trending markets

Clear signals

Works across stocks, crypto, forex

Lagging indicator

Poor performance in sideways markets

Histogram confirmation

Zero-line filtering

200-period moving average filter

//@version=6
strategy("MACD Strategy", overlay=true)

fastLength = input(12, "Fast length")
slowlength = input(26, "Slow length")
MACDLength = input(9, "MACD length")

MACD = ta.ema(close, fastLength) - ta.ema(close, slowlength)
aMACD = ta.ema(MACD, MACDLength)
delta = MACD - aMACD

if ta.crossover(delta, 0)
    strategy.entry("MacdLE", strategy.long)

if ta.crossunder(delta, 0)
    strategy.entry("MacdSE", strategy.short)
